intro: Schizoloma scoparium, commonly known as the bristly bladdernut, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, spiny seed pods that resemble small bladders. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and has alternate, ovate leaves with a rough texture. Its flowers are unisexual, with male and female flowers occurring on separate plants, and it produces a yellowish latex when the stems are damaged. Schizoloma scoparium is often found in the understory of eastern deciduous forests.
